summary: Rumex acetosella, commonly known as red sorrel, sheep's sorrel, field sorrel and sour weed, is a species of flowering plant in the buckwheat family Polygonaceae. Native to Eurasia and the British Isles, the plant and its subspecies are common perennial weeds. It has green arrowhead-shaped leaves and red-tinted deeply ridged stems, and it sprouts from an aggressive and spreading rhizome. The flowers emerge from a tall, upright stem. Female flowers are maroon in color.

flower.description: It is unisexual, male flowers have 6 stamens, female flowers have 3 stigmas, and the tip is thinly ground like a tassel. Seeds have three ridges. length 1.5mm

shape.stem: Propagated by rhizomes, stems are erect and have vertical ridges. very branched
shape.leaf: Radical leaves grow in clumps, and the leaves are 3-5 cm long and 1-2 cm wide, spear-shaped. The tip is sharp, and the ear-like protrusions spread to the left and right at the bottom. Cauline leaves are alternate and lanceolate.
shape.fruit: Seed ridges 3, 1.5 mm long, light brown.

introduction.period: After the opening of the port - 1921
